event.name: BAML Demos!
event.description:
BAML Agent Demos and Learnings
Join us as the Boundary team dives deep into agent building with BAML! This week, our team tackled two main goals: to identify BAML's current pain points and to craft helpful guides for developers. 

These repos will be open-sourced in our examples repo: github.com/boundaryml/baml-examples
Agenda:
10:00 - 10:05: Kickoff
10:05 - 10:15: Antonio: Track Feature/Bug Requests from Discord -> Notion
Our team addresses community-driven issues every Friday. Antonio demonstrates an AI agent that keeps track of feature and bug requests in Notion, so we no longer need to rely on Vaibhav and Aaron.
10:15 - 10:25: Sam: Making Docs Not Suck
Discover how Sam built tools that intelligently inject links into documentation, making sure there’s never any hallucinations or broken links!
10:25 - 10:35: Greg: Claude Draws with GIMP
With Claude’s computer vision capabilities, Greg tackles the complex task of getting a model to perform detailed, creative tasks—like drawing.
10:35 - 10:45: Vaibhav & Aaron: New BAML Tooling?!
I promise it'll be worth it!
10:45 - 11:00: Q&A
Don't miss this chance to learn from our team’s insights on what works, what doesn’t, and where BAML is heading!

event.name: BAML Workshops: Avanced Prompt Engineering Techniques (YC F24 only)
event.description:
Join us for a hands-on session diving into advanced techniques for building and optimizing AI pipelines. A big thanks to AWS for sponsoring snacks and the venue! This event is for the YC F24 batch only—please register with your company email so we can confirm attendance.
In this workshop, we’ll explore:
Maximizing LLM Performance: Strategies to get the most out of large language models.Eval techniques: What works beyond LLMs as a judge? Can LLMs even judge their own outputs?
Managing Latency: Practical methods for reducing delays in your pipeline.
Improving Accuracy: Techniques to boost the reliability of model outputs.
Improving Consistency: How do your customers feel confident they'll get the same response
Understanding Technical Challenges:Why are LLMs still non-deterministic even when temperature == 0 or a seed is set?
Why are log probabilities unreliable as a confidence metric?
Why you probably shouldn't fine-tune (for now)
Scaling Prompt Engineering: Best practices for managing codebases with hundreds of prompts.
This interactive session will include live coding, technical explanations, and plenty of time for Q&A. Bring your laptop, as you’ll have the opportunity to code along and apply these techniques in real time.
In order to maximize technical depth, space is limited!

This event is organized by Boundary (YC W23) and the speaker is Vaibhav Gupta. We are building BAML - https://www.github.com/boundaryml/baml
event.description_md:
Join us for a hands-on session diving into advanced techniques for building and optimizing AI pipelines. A big thanks to AWS for sponsoring snacks and the venue! This event is for the YC F24 batch only—please register with your company email so we can confirm attendance.

In this workshop, we’ll explore:

* **Maximizing LLM Performance**: Strategies to get the most out of large language models.

  * Eval techniques: What works beyond LLMs as a judge? Can LLMs even judge their own outputs?
  * **Managing Latency**: Practical methods for reducing delays in your pipeline.
  * Improving Accuracy: Techniques to boost the reliability of model outputs.
  * **Improving Consistency**: How do your customers feel confident they'll get the same response

* **Understanding Technical Challenges:**

  * Why are LLMs still non-deterministic even when `temperature == 0` or a seed is set?
  * Why are log probabilities unreliable as a confidence metric?
  * Why you probably shouldn't fine-tune (for now)

* **Scaling Prompt Engineering**: Best practices for managing codebases with hundreds of prompts.

This interactive session will include live coding, technical explanations, and plenty of time for Q\&A. Bring your laptop, as you’ll have the opportunity to code along and apply these techniques in real time.

In order to maximize technical depth, space is limited!

This event is organized by Boundary (YC W23) and the speaker is [Vaibhav Gupta](https://bookface.ycombinator.com/user/15777). We are building BAML - <https://www.github.com/boundaryml/baml>

event.name: BAML Workshops: Advanced Prompt Engineering Techniques (Seattle)
event.description:
Join us for a hands-on session diving into advanced techniques for building and optimizing AI / LLM applications.
Co-hosted by: Boundary X AI Tinkerers X Foundations
What to Expect 🚀
This interactive session will include live coding, technical explanations, and Q&A.
We’ll explore various topics including -
Maximizing LLM performance:
Improve Accuracy: Techniques to boost the reliability of model outputs and reduce hallucinations. How to go from 90% to 99%?
Improve Consistency: How can your customers get the same response every single time?
Manage Latency: Practical methods for reducing delays in your AI pipeline.
Eval techniques: What works beyond LLMs as a judge? Can LLMs even judge their own outputs?
Challenges devs face when working with LLM:
Why are LLMs still non-deterministic even when temperature == 0 or a seed is set?
How to manage and scale your codebase when you have hundreds of prompts that need to be managed by engineers and non-engineers?
Why are log probabilities unreliable as a confidence metric?
What is wrong with token-based streaming and how semantic streaming is better.
Key Details 🗓️
Date: December 13, 2024 (Friday)
Time: 3:00 PM - 5:00 PM
Location: Foundations Seattle - 1605 Boylston Ave, Seattle, WA 98122
Agenda ⏰
3:00 PM: Presentation w/ live coding
4:30 PM: Q&A
5:00 PM: Wrap-up networking
Who is this for? 🤖
This event is specifically curated for:
Developers, AI engineers, and data scientists that are actively working on AI pipelines.
Ideally, you should have already used an LLM API programmatically in your codebase, or have built server-client architectures before.
Prior experience with getting structured output from AI pipeline is nice-to-have.
Bring your laptop, as you’ll have the opportunity to code along and apply these techniques in real-time!
Meet the Speaker 🧑‍💻
Meet Vaibhav Gupta, one of the creators of BAML. He has worked almost 10 years in AI performance optimization at places like Google, Microsoft, and D. E. Shaw. He loves diving deep and chatting about anything related to Gen AI and Computer Vision!
What is BAML and Boundary?
BAML is a domain-specific language to generate structured outputs from LLMs.
The team at Boundary created BAML to help developers build reliable Agents, Chatbots with RAG, data extraction from PDFs, and other AI apps.
What is AI Tinkerers?
AI Tinkerers is a global network of passionate AI practitioners working to push the boundaries of language models and generative AI.
What is Foundations?
Foundations is a community for tech founders in Seattle. Its mission is to build a thriving startup ecosystem by efficiently supporting founders through networking, mentorship, and shared experiences.
event.description_md:
Join us for a hands-on session diving into advanced techniques for building and optimizing AI / LLM applications.

Co-hosted by: Boundary X AI Tinkerers X Foundations

# What to Expect 🚀

This interactive session will include live coding, technical explanations, and Q\&A. 

We’ll explore various topics including -

Maximizing LLM performance: 

* Improve Accuracy: Techniques to boost the reliability of model outputs and reduce hallucinations. How to go from 90% to 99%? 
* Improve Consistency: How can your customers get the same response every single time?
* Manage Latency: Practical methods for reducing delays in your AI pipeline.
* Eval techniques: What works beyond LLMs as a judge? Can LLMs even judge their own outputs?

Challenges devs face when working with LLM:

* Why are LLMs still non-deterministic even when temperature == 0 or a seed is set?
* How to manage and scale your codebase when you have hundreds of prompts that need to be managed by engineers and non-engineers?
* Why are log probabilities unreliable as a confidence metric?
* What is wrong with token-based streaming and how semantic streaming is better.

# Key Details 🗓️

* Date: December 13, 2024 (Friday)
* Time: 3:00 PM - 5:00 PM 
* Location: Foundations Seattle - 1605 Boylston Ave, Seattle, WA 98122

# Agenda ⏰

* 3:00 PM: Presentation w/ live coding
* 4:30 PM: Q\&A
* 5:00 PM: Wrap-up networking

# Who is this for? 🤖

This event is specifically curated for:

* Developers, AI engineers, and data scientists that are actively working on AI pipelines.
* Ideally, you should have already used an LLM API programmatically in your codebase, or have built server-client architectures before.
* Prior experience with getting structured output from AI pipeline is nice-to-have.

_Bring your laptop, as you’ll have the opportunity to code along and apply these techniques in real-time!_

# Meet the Speaker 🧑‍💻

Meet [Vaibhav Gupta](https://www.linkedin.com/in/vaigup/), one of the creators of BAML. He has worked almost 10 years in AI performance optimization at places like Google, Microsoft, and D. E. Shaw. He loves diving deep and chatting about anything related to Gen AI and Computer Vision! 

## What is [BAML](https://docs.boundaryml.com/home) and [Boundary](https://www.boundaryml.com/)?

BAML is a domain-specific language to generate structured outputs from LLMs.

The team at Boundary created BAML to help developers build reliable Agents, Chatbots with RAG, data extraction from PDFs, and other AI apps.

## What is [AI Tinkerers](https://aitinkerers.org/p/welcome)?

AI Tinkerers is a global network of passionate AI practitioners working to push the boundaries of language models and generative AI.

## What is [Foundations](https://seattlefoundations.org/)?

Foundations is a community for tech founders in Seattle. Its mission is to build a thriving startup ecosystem by efficiently supporting founders through networking, mentorship, and shared experiences.

event.name: 🦄 ai that works: large scale classification
event.description:
🦄 ai that works



LLMs are great at classification from 5, 10, maybe even 50 categories. But how do we deal with situations when we have over 1000? Perhaps its an ever changing list of categories?
This week, join Dex and Vaibhav as they deep dive into multiple techniques to approach this problem.
Pre-reading
To prevent repeating the basics, we recommend you come in having already understanding some of the tooling we will be using:
Discord
Cursor (A vscode replacement)
Programming languagesApplication Logic: Python or Typescript or Go
Prompting: BAML (recommend video)
Meet the Speaker 🧑‍💻
Meet Vaibhav Gupta, one of the creators of BAML and YC alum. He spent 10 years in AI performance optimization at places like Google, Microsoft, and D. E. Shaw. He loves diving deep and chatting about anything related to Gen AI and Computer Vision! 

Meet Dex Horothy, founder at Human Layer - a YC company. He spent 10+ years building devops tools at Replicated, Sprout Social and JPL. DevOps junkie turned AI Engineer.
event.description_md:
🦄 ai that works

> A weekly conversation about how we can all get the most juice out of todays models with @hellovai & @dexhorthy
>
> <https://www.github.com/hellovai/ai-that-works>

![](https://images.lumacdn.com/cdn-cgi/image/format=auto,dpr=2,anim=false,background=white,quality=75,width=800/editor-images/94/7a864a4d-3525-4531-b5c1-c9d25ea9b46a.png)

​LLMs are great at classification from 5, 10, maybe even 50 categories. But how do we deal with situations when we have over 1000? Perhaps its an ever changing list of categories?

This week, join Dex and Vaibhav as they deep dive into multiple techniques to approach this problem.

# Pre-reading

To prevent repeating the basics, we recommend you come in having already understanding some of the tooling we will be using:

* Discord

* Cursor (A vscode replacement)

* Programming languages

  * Application Logic: Python or Typescript or Go
  * Prompting: BAML ([recommend video](https://gloochat.notion.site/benefits-of-baml))

# Meet the Speaker 🧑‍💻

​​Meet [Vaibhav Gupta](https://www.linkedin.com/in/vaigup/), one of the creators of BAML and YC alum. He spent 10 years in AI performance optimization at places like Google, Microsoft, and D. E. Shaw. He loves diving deep and chatting about anything related to Gen AI and Computer Vision! \
\
Meet [Dex Horothy](https://x.com/dexhorthy), founder at Human Layer - a YC company. He spent 10+ years building devops tools at Replicated, Sprout Social and JPL. DevOps junkie turned AI Engineer.

We've all heard a lot about memory. There are some useful abstractions out there that help you bootstrap memory quickly and add it to agents, but at the end of the day, you may want to open the black box and tune things yourself. Without a deep understanding of all the options for memory and how these tools are architected, its hard to weight the tradeoffs outside of basic vibe checks.
In this episode, we'll build a recipe for AI agents that explores a few different memory techniques and how you can build an open-box implementation that you can tune and customize over time.

event.name: 🦄 ai that works: Eval-ing multiple models for each prompt
event.description:
🦄 ai that works




AI That Works #16 will be a super-practical deep dive into real-world examples and techniques for evaluating a single prompt against multiple models. While this is a commonly heralded use case for Evals, e.g. "how do we know if the new model is better" / "how do we know if the new model breaks anything", there's not a ton of practical examples out there for real-world use cases.

On this episode we'll do a ton of hands-on live coding to look at different ways to slice and dice your prompt library to test and evolve it while understanding performance with different models.

By popular demand, AI That Works #17 will dive deep on a new kind of context engineering: managing research, specs, and planning to get the most of coding agents and coding CLIs.
You've heard people bragging about spending thousands/mo on Claude Code, maxing out Amp limits, and much more. Now Dex and Vaibhav are gonna share some tips and tricks for pushing AI coding tools to their absolute limits, while still shipping well-tested, bug-free code. This isn't vibe-coding, this is something completely different.

Skipping the MCP and having claude write its own scripts to interact with external systems
Creating internal knowledge graphs with markdown files
How to blend agentic retrieval and search with deterministic context packing

event.name: 🦄 ai that works: Voice Agents and Supervisor Threading
event.description:
🦄 ai that works

On #19 we talked about workflows for interruptible agents. One of the most popular segments was on how to combine a small model for a voice agent, with a smarter+slower instruction-following model to observe the conversation and inject steering into the smaller model's context window.
On this week's episode, we'll dive deep into the architecture of how you can build supervisor-threaded systems, and ship real working code you can pull down and use to build your own high-quality voice agents.
